bestBHT.bht: The disciples, having witnessed Jesus' public journey to Jerusalem and the miracles that accompanied it, believed that it signified the imminent establishment of his earthly kingdom. However, Jesus spoke a parable to correct their misconception and teach them that there would be a period of separation before the full realization of his kingdom. This parable aimed to refute the idea that the Messianic kingdom would immediately appear without the prior departure of the Master. It emphasized the need for spiritual discernment in understanding the manifestation of his kingdom.

Henry Alford: The distance of Jericho from Jerusalem was 150 stadia = 16 English miles and 6 furlongs.
They imagined that the present journey to Jerusalem, undertaken as it had been with such publicity, and accompanied with such wonderful miracles.
They imagined that the present journey to Jerusalem was for the purpose of revealing and establishing the Messiah’s kingdom.
Albert Barnes: To 'correct that notion' seems to have been the main design of this parable.
Thus intimating that 'he' would also go away 'before' he would completely set up his kingdom.
That the reign of the Messiah would immediately commence. He spoke the parable to 'correct' that expectation.
Marvin Vincent: Appear [αναφαινεσθαι] . Only here and Acts 21:3. It means to be brought to light; shown forth. The common phrase show up [ανα] represents it.
John Calvin: It was next to a prodigy that the disciples, after having been so frequently warned as to the approaching death of Christ, flew aside from it to think of his kingdom.
There were two mistakes; first, that they pictured to themselves rest and happiness without the cross; secondly, that they judged of the kingdom of God according to their own carnal sense.
That knowledge immediately degenerates into vain imaginations, which either overturn or obscure the power of his kingdom.
Philip Schaff: The parable was designed to controvert the idea that the glory of the Messianic kingdom would appear at once, without a previous separation of the Master from His servants, to whom He would return as King.
This public journey to Jerusalem, attended by so many miracles and impressive discourses, was regarded as introductory to a Messianic kingdom of temporal splendor.
The parable was spoken in the house, probably from the open room looking into the court, where a good part of the multitude that had followed Him had doubtless remained and murmured.
Archibald T. Robertson: It is a Hebrew idiom seen also in Luke 20:1 he added to send"
To appear (αναφαινεσθα). Present passive infinitive of an old verb to be made manifest, to be shown up.
John Gill: he added a parable to the word
because he was nigh to Jerusalem
the scope and design of the following parable, is to refute the notion of a temporal kingdom, and its near approach
John Wesley: They thought the kingdom of God — A glorious temporal kingdom, would immediately appear.

bhtAttempts.bht: The disciples, having witnessed Jesus' public journey to Jerusalem and the miracles that accompanied it, believed that it signified the imminent establishment of his earthly kingdom. However, Jesus spoke a parable to correct their misconception and to teach them that there would be a period of separation before the full realization of his kingdom. This parable was spoken in a house, likely to those who remained from the multitude that had followed him. It aimed to refute the idea that the Messianic kingdom would immediately appear without the prior departure of the Master. The disciples' misunderstanding represented a failure to grasp the true nature of the kingdom of God, as they focused on earthly glory rather than the spiritual implications of the cross. Jesus, therefore, used this parable to correct their misguided expectations and to emphasize the need for spiritual discernment in understanding the manifestation of his kingdom.

The disciples, having witnessed Jesus' public journey to Jerusalem and the miracles that accompanied it, believed that it signified the imminent establishment of his earthly kingdom. However, Jesus spoke a parable to correct their misconception and teach them that there would be a period of separation before the full realization of his kingdom. This parable aimed to refute the idea that the Messianic kingdom would immediately appear without the prior departure of the Master. It emphasized the need for spiritual discernment in understanding the manifestation of his kingdom.

The disciples' expectation of an immediate earthly kingdom, fueled by Jesus' public journey to Jerusalem and the miracles performed, prompted him to speak a parable, correcting their misconception of the kingdom's timing. This parable aimed to establish the necessity of a period of separation before the realization of the Messianic kingdom. Jesus emphasized the need for spiritual discernment in discerning the true nature and manifestation of his kingdom, countering their earthly-focused expectations and urging them to embrace the spiritual implications of the cross.

The disciples' anticipation of an immediate, glorious earthly kingdom, based on Jesus' public journey to Jerusalem and the accompanying miracles, prompted him to deliver a parable to correct their misguided perception. Jesus aimed to counter the notion that the Messianic kingdom would appear right away without a prior separation of the Master from his servants. The parable emphasizes the need for spiritual discernment in understanding the manifestation of God's kingdom, challenging their carnal understanding and redirecting their focus towards the cross.

The disciples' anticipation of an immediate earthly kingdom, based on Jesus' public and miraculous journey to Jerusalem, prompted him to correct their misconception through a parable. He sought to refute the belief that the Messianic kingdom would appear without the Master separating from his servants beforehand. Jesus emphasized the need for spiritual discernment, challenging their carnal understanding and redirecting their attention towards the significance of the cross in comprehending the manifestation of God's kingdom.
